p: The gold standard for the confirmation of a diagnosis is to prove the presence of the specific antibodies, but the absence of autoantibodies does not exclude the diagnosis [ 14]. It is important to test for antibodies in the serum as well as in the CSF, because some of the antibodies may be detected only in the CSF. Furthermore, the CSF and serum antibodies can differ, but the clinical presentation usually correlates with the CSF antibodies. In addition, the concentrations of the antibodies in CSF and serum may vary. There are fewer false positive or negative results with the determination of antibodies in CSF, than in serum [ 14].
